sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving coordination compounds.
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction between [Co(en)2Cl2]Cl and NaNO2 to form [Co(en)2(NO2)2]Cl and NaCl, given the following information: 

[Co(en)2Cl2]Cl and [Co(en)2(NO2)2]Cl have a ΔHf° of -288 kJ/mol and -136 kJ/mol, respectively. The ΔHf° of NaNO2 and NaCl are -463.2 kJ/mol and -411.2 kJ/mol, respectively. Assume that the reaction is conducted at a constant pressure and temperature of 298 K.
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the following formula:

ΔH°(reaction) = Σ ΔHf°(products) - Σ ΔHf°(reactants)

The reaction is:
[Co(en)2Cl2]Cl + NaNO2 → [Co(en)2(NO2)2]Cl + NaCl

ΔHf° values are given as:
[Co(en)2Cl2]Cl: -288 kJ/mol
[Co(en)2(NO2)2]Cl: -136 kJ/mol
NaNO2: -463.2 kJ/mol
NaCl: -411.2 kJ/mol

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

ΔH°(reaction) = ([-136 kJ/mol] + [-411.2 kJ/mol]) - ([-288 kJ/mol] + [-463.2 kJ/mol])

ΔH°(reaction) = (-547.2 kJ/mol) - (-751.2 kJ/mol)

ΔH°(reaction) = 204 kJ/mol

So, the standard enthalpy change for the reaction is 204 kJ/mol.
